(40) 301stConclusions,Minute 1.)MilitaryOperations.Libya.BomberCommandGreece- The Chiefs of Staff reported as follows :-In the northern sector Italian resistance was still energeticnear Pogradets. The Greeks had advanced steadily from one to three miles between Upper Skumbi and the River Devoli.In the Central Sector Mount Ostrovice had been crossed by the greeks. Kelcyre had been evacuated by the Italians who had,apparently, given up the Kelcyre-Tepelene Gorge.In the Epirus Sector there had been an advance to Pigerra onthe coast 15 kilometres north of Santi Quaranta.Air Operations. jjay 6th, 7th and 8th December.-An average of 80 enemyEnemy Activity, aircraft had been over this country each day. The casualties hadbeen two certain and one probable. We had lost one machine.Night of 6th December. Seventy enemy machine had been overBristol.Night of 7th December. There had been no enemy activity over this country.Night of 8th December. There had been 390 sorties over theLondon area. Two hundred and ninety enemy aircraft had been engaged and 100 of them had done two trips.The enemy casualties had been nil on the night 6th December.On the night 8th December two enemy bombers had been shot downby A.A. fire and one by our fighters.Night of 6th December. Sixty-six machines had been sent out to bomb enemy aerodromes and ports.Night of 7th December. Seventy-three machines had been sent out and a heavy attack had been made on Dusseldorf with very successful results.Night of 8th December. Ninety-two machines had been sent out. Seventeen had bombed Dusseldorf and 41 had bombed theenemy submarine base at Bordeaux. One of our machines hadclaimed a direct hit on a submarine.From all these bombing operations 7 of our machines had beenmissing and 2 had come down in the sea off our own coast, the crewsbeing drowned.Brest and Lorient had been bombed by the Coastal Commandon the previous Friday and Saturday nights.7th December. Twenty Blenheims had attacked Valona anda hit had been registered on a large ship. Five of our machines had been lost.7th December. Eleven Wellingtons had successfully attacked the aerodrome at Tripoli and all 5 hangars had been hit.Night of 8th December. Operations had been undertakenagainst Benghazi. No news had been received regarding the resultbut the Italians claimed to have shot down four of our machines.One Dutch ship, the Stolnyk (2,489 tons) and two British ships,the Calabria (9,515 tons) and the Empire Jaguar (5,186 tons) hadShippingLosses. been torpedoed on the 7th and 8th December. The Hertford(British, 10,923 tons) had been mined off Spencer Gulf, SouthAustralia, on. the 7th December.Recent gales had caused the dispersion of convoy HX 91 and32 ships of this convoy had been in distress, 14 of them being ashore.[22006-1] B 2Greece.Libya.NavalOperations1. The Prime Minister and the Secretary of State for Warexplained to the War Cabinet the scope of operations which hadbeen begun that morning near Sidi Barrani. A record is containedin the Secretary's Standard File of War Cabinet Conclusions. Action by theCarnarvonCastle.Destroyers had also received damage owing to the bad weather.Tugs had been despatched to render assistance.Further reports had been received of the action between theCarnarvon Castle and an enemy raider on the 5th December. TheCarnarvon Castle had been outranged, and the enemy had openedfire at 17,000 yards with great accuracy, twenty minutes before theCarnarvon Castle had been within range. The latter's main aerialand fire control had been damaged early in the action. nevertheless the Carnarvon Castle had continued to press the raider which hadfinally withdrawn under cover of a smoke screen. The CarnarvonCastle had sustained 23 hits and the raider had been hit ten times.The Prime Minister said that this was a most creditable action for an unprotected ship.The Submarine Sunfish had reported that she had sunk a 4,000ton merchant ship off the Norwegian coast on the 5th December andhad probably hit a 4,000 ton Tanker on the 7th December.The Diomede reported that on the 8th she had intercepted theIdarzoald (German, 5,035 tons) which had scuttled herself.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Foreign 2. The Home Secretary said that the attack on London on theprevious night had done considerable damage to communications,house property, public and commercial buildings and oil installations.A large number of incendiary and of explosive-incendiary bombs hadbeen used and there had been several heavy fires. Land mines had also been dropped. The casualties had been : London : 85 killed, 534 injured.Elsewhere : 17 killed, 76 injured.At the request of the Prime Minister, the Minister of aircraft production gave an account of a meeting held that morning to review the progress made in methods of defence against night raiders. TheMinister said that, while we should not look for any immediate andspectacular results, many promising developments were beingresolutely driven forward.The Minister of Labour and National Service referred to thesuggestion that had been made at an earlier Meeting of the war.M. (40) 296th Cabinet, that Fighter Squadrons should carry out occasional patrolsConclusions, by day over areas which had been heavily bombed, e.g., SouthamptonMinute 2.) an(j Coventry. The Secretary of State for A ir undertook to look further intothis suggestion, subject to the general understanding that nothing should be allowed to distract the energies of the Royal Air force from their essential task of providing the best possible fighterdefence for this country.The War Cabinet took note of these statements.Parliament.Meeting place.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 283rdConclusions,Minute 9.)4. The War Cabinet were informed that some damage hadbeen done to the Palace of Westminster on the previous night. TheHouse of Commons would meet on the following day in the Annexe.The House of Lords had arranged to meet in the Palace of West-minster on Tuesday, the 10th December. This arrangement wouldbe adhered to, but thereafter arrangements would probably be madefor the House of Lords to meet in the Annexe so long as the Houseof Commons held its meetings there.Royal Air Force.The coastal command.5. The Prime Minister informed the War Cabinet that, as theresult of his enquiry into the relations between the Admiralty and coastal Command, a solution had been arrived at which was satis-factory both to the Admiralty and the Air Ministry. The issues involved were quite unsuitable for Parliamentary debate, and itwould be necessary to resist a demand for such a debate which wasto be made in the House of Lords on the following day. Least of allought the Government to pledge itself that Parliament would always be consulted in advance before decisions were taken affecting the relationship between the three Defence Services.The War Cabinet agreed with the Prime Minister's viewson this matter.Espionage. q The Home Secretary informed the War Cabinet that twoTrial and spies who had entered this country by boat and had been capturedexecution of in September, had since been tried and sentenced to death. Anspies. appeal for clemency had been made, but he saw no reason whysentence should not be carried out. The men would accordingly behanged on the following day.Some discussion ensued whether these men should be hanged orshot. On the one hand, it was urged that public opinion generally would support the view that a spy, when not a traitor to his own country, should be shot and not hanged. On the other hand, it waspointed out that these men were civilians and not soldiers; that theyhad been tried by a Civil Court and sentenced to death by hanging;and it would be very difficult to find good reason to vary thissentence.The War Cabinet (1) Invited the Home Secretary to examine this point further,but not to delay the execution of these men.(2) Took note that a communique would be issued when the men had been executed.aircraft production.Dispersal ofaircraftfactories.7. The War Cabinet had before them Memoranda by theMinister of Aircraft Production and the Minister of Food, on the dispersal of aircraft factories (W.P. (40) 467 and 474).In the course of discussion the following points were made : (1) The Minister of Labour and National Service asked that he might be informed when productive establishments were dispersed, in order that he might deal with the trans-ference of labour involved. (2) The Lord Privy Seal urged that it was a dangerous position that industries should be free to leave areas because theyhad been heavily bombed. If this process was allowedto continue there would be a great loss of productivecapacity.The War Cabinet-(d) Took note of the Paper by the Minister of Aircraft Pro-duction in regard to the dispersal of aircraft factories,including the proposal that any premises not in actualoccupation, even if earmarked for use by some other ^Department, should be at the disposal of the Minister, ifremoval or dispersal was necessitated by enemy action.(b) Agreed that the procedure in (a) above should be subject tothe following conditions : (i) that notification was given immediately to theDepartment concerned, which would have theright to ask for the return of the premises;(ii) that, while discussion on these matters would normally be settled between the Departments con-cerned, any Minister concerned should have theright to refer any point in dispute for settlement,either by the existing priority machinery or by reference to the War Cabinet :(c) Took note that the Lord Presidents Committee had underconsideration the measures necessary to strengthen theorganisation for dealing with warehouse and factoryaccommodation generally, and for improving the system for allocating such accommodation.Germany. 8.
